newsitem.title: HONG KONG: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - Sept 3.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - HK newspaper headlines - Sept 3.

text.p: -- WEN WEI PO -- Xinhua News Agency Hong Kong branch deputy director Zhang Junsheng said Chinese vice premier Qian Qichen had written to the Democratic Party, expressing hope that the party would get involved in the setting up of the future Hong Kong government according to principles laid down by China.

-- MING PAO DAILY NEWS -- Most senior Hong Kong government officials think Chief Justice Sir Ti Liang Yang, who is expected to announce his candidacy to become the territory's future Chief Executive, was incapable, indecisive and easily influenced by other people. But some thought his weak personality may form a good pair with a tough deputy like chief secretary Anson Chan.

-- ORIENTAL DAILY NEWS -- Local Preparatory Committee member Xu Simin confirmed that Chief Justice Sir Ti Liang Yan was intending to run for the post of the future Chief Executive. Yang will come back to Hong Kong from vacation later this month.

-- SING TAO DAILY-- The Bar Association decided not to nominate any members to join the Selection Committee that will choose the Chief Executive. Chairman Gladys Lee said she hoped the decision would not hamper future communication with Beijing.

-- HONG KONG ECONOMIC TIMES -- Swire Properties announced it was releasing 48 units of a residential development in North Point, at an average price of HK$6,400 per square foot. The whole project could bring in HK$4 billion in total.

-- SOUTH CHINA MORNING POST -- Morgan Grenfell Asset Management halted trading in three funds and suspendd a fund manager after it said it discovered possible irregularities in some unquoted securities held by the portfolios.
-- Attacks on plans to implement major increases in charges at the new Chek Lap Kok airport had broadened, with calls for discussions on the plans.

-- MING PAO DAILY NEWS -- Because of the recent anti-America sentiment in China, a documentary called Challange has become popular in Guangzhou. It was about the Korean War, and many Chinese enjoyed watching how the Americans were defeated.
